Articles.Content: Actually, most of 'us' use OS X for other than gaming as first priority, but it is a valid expectation to have a properly working game on every platform that it is being sold for. I also went back from 0.90 to a previous version, because the memory leaking was ruining my favourite game... But let's hope Squad fixed this for 1.0

OSX? Mac OS?

I didn't know there was a memory leak on that OS. Well hope they fix it for you 2.5% who use Macintosh Computers for gaming.

Mac OSX is actually a lot more viable for gaming than it ever used to be. Steam has quite a few games (including AAA) titles available for it. Granted, they're graphics drivers are still behind what's available for Windows and Linux, and Apple tends to prioritize skinny and quiet over proper cooling so you'll have a lot of throttling and overheating issues, but gaming is one area where Apple has improved a lot in recent years. Disclaimer: I don't (and probably won't ever as long as Apple continues to use planned obsolescence and "magic" to sell their products) own any Apple products.

Edit: As the previous post said, it's reasonable to assume that if a game is available for a platform it should work properly on it. There's not much worse in gaming than your chosen platform getting a terribly optimized, crippled port of an otherwise awesome game (other than possibly not having the game available at all due to exclusivity agreements).

I'm glad that there's been so much gratitude in this thread. Felipe and his team deserve all the praise and thanks and more. Kerbal Space Program is quite simply extraordinary. I've played a lot of computer games since the day I took my new Apple Galaxian diskette out of its ziploc bag (forget reminiscing about the days when we went to the store to buy software in a box...I remember when there wasn't even the box!), but I've never had an experience quite like KSP. Outside of the Civilization series, it has no rival in terms of hours played; and in terms of being enriching and rewarding, it stands alone.

I can't believe it's almost three years now since I jumped on the bandwagon (for the criminally low price of $15...add me to the list of people eager to buy a bit of DLC down the road). I hope I'm still playing--and there are still new things to experience--three years from now.

the Lab now works much more like a long-term research facility. Now, when you run experiments, you can transfer data to the lab just as before, but instead of a quick process for a small boost in the xmit factor, the data fed to the lab will generate a steady output of Science for a very long time, ultimately yielding far more science than transmitting or even recovering. This, of course, requires the labs to be manned by scientists, and have a steady supply of electricity. It should greatly increase the benefits of setting up orbiting science stations and surface bases, however, and also give you good reason to visit them every now and then. (The data does decay after a while, and the labs can only hold so much processed data before having to transmit, so donÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t expect to be able to timewarp your way to infinite science)

I have played this game longer than EverQuest and Asheron's Call.

And it has just begun, this is just 1.0....oh my.

Well, It is finally here. Release Day.

Back in 2011, I wondered if Squad would make it. I started playing with version .7. I posted a lengthy diatribe on their development maturity (or lack thereof) back then, and a long list of milestones that they would need to achieve to make it. Unfortunately it was eaten by the great April Forum crash.

I am happy to note that all of my "predictions" came true. Squad really buckled down and became a serious gaming development team, comprising development, staging, QA, play testing, bug tracking, Project management, marketing, social media, kerbalcon, and so many other major activities that were needed to get to this point.

I had faith in you then, and plunked my money down a soon as I could after you started taking "donations" as they were called back then (I paid 10 bucks). I remember flying to the sun when there was no sun. I remember trying to figure out how in the H** do I get back to kerbin???

I remember "begging" for docking back around .15. I remember so many days of patiently listening to all the moaners about an alpha game that had much more polish than most alpha games. I remember the day you hit 25,000 forum members... I remember...

Anyway, thanks for creating such a fantastic gaming environment. I will enjoy this game long into the future. Thanks to the community that was patient with me as I started modding and thanks to those that use my meager offerings and push me to make it better. Thanks to the amazing modders that have made KSP something special since the beginning, and that have helped me to "learn the ropes".

Finally, thanks harvester and team for "seeing it through" when it seemed like the pressure could break you all. Congrats on getting married in the midst of an alpha release, and to the rest of the team who experienced much of the same obstacles, joy and excitement that comes with developing something special.

I salute you!
